courses.name: Introduction to Journalism and News Literacy I

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the social, historical, philosophical, and practical contexts of journalism. The course will examine the skills required to become news literate. The course will look at various types of media and the role of the journalist. Students will be introduced to specific techniques to distinguish reliable news from so-called fake news. Media coverage and analysis of current issues will be discussed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Journalism and News Literacy I

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

courses.name: Contemporary Issues in Law and Ethics

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of the key legal and ethical issues facing Canadian journalists, with an emphasis on the practical: what a journalist needs to know to avoid legal problems and develop strategies for handling ethical challenges. This course is taught at Centennial College and is open only to students in the Specialist (Joint) program in Journalism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary Issues in Law and Ethics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 10.0 credits including: JOUB01H3 and JOUB02H3 and ACMB02H3
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: JOUB11H3 and JOUB14H3 and JOUB18H3 and JOUB19H3

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Indicator: R

Restricted to students in the following groups:
SCSPEJOU - Specialist (Joint) Program in Journalism

Centennial College Joint Program Courses will be automatically enrolled by the Joint Program Co-coordinator.

If you have questions or concerns please contact Sayilaja Kalaimohan: SKalaimohan@centennialcollege.ca

cmCourseInfo.description: An examination of Canadian coverage of immigration and transnational issues. With the shift in Canada's demographics, media outlets are struggling to adapt to new realities. We will explore how media frame the public policy debate on immigration, multiculturalism, diaspora communities, and transnational issues which link Canada to the developing world.
cmCourseInfo.title: Covering Immigration and Transnational Issues
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: JOUA01H3 and JOUA02H3

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Indicator: R

SCMAJJSS - Major Program in Media, Journalism and Digital Cultures (Arts) - Journalism Studies Stream

This JOU course is taught at UTSC

cmCourseInfo.description: The course examines the representation of race, gender, class and power in the media, traditional journalistic practices and newsroom culture. It will prepare students who wish to work in a media-related industry with a critical perspective towards understanding the marginalization of particular groups in the media.
cmCourseInfo.title: Critical Journalism
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 4.0 credits including JOUA01H3 and JOUA02H3

cmCourseInfo.description: Students analyze professional interviews, critique student interviews, conduct research and interview newsmakers. This is as much a "people" skills course as it is a course in learning how to ask the right questions. This course is taught at Centennial College and is open only to students in the Journalism Joint Program.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Interviewing Techniques
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 12 credits, including JOUA06H3 and JOUB11H3 and JOUB14H3 and JOUB18H3
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: JOUB03H3 and JOUB10H3 and JOUB17H3 and JOUB20H3

cmCourseInfo.description: Through research and practice, students gain an understanding of news judgment and value, finding and developing credible sources and developing interviewing, editing and curating skills. This course is taught at Centennial College and is open only to students in the Specialist (Joint) program in Journalism.
cmCourseInfo.title: News Reporting
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 10.0  credits including: JOUB01H3 and JOUB02H3 and ACMB02H3
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: JOUA06H3 and JOUB14H3 and JOUB18H3 and JOUB19H3

cmCourseInfo.description: Today, content creators and consumers both use mobile tools and technologies. Students will explore the principles of design, including responsive design, and how they apply to various platforms and devices. This course is taught at Centennial College and is open only to students in the Specialist (Joint) program in Journalism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Mobile Journalism
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 10.0 credits including: JOUB01H3 and JOUB02H3 and ACMB02H3; students must have a minimum CGPA of 2.0
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: JOUA06H3 and JOUB11H3 and JOUB18H3 and JOUB19H3

cmCourseInfo.description: Applying photo-journalism principles to the journalist's tool of choice, the smartphone. Students will take professional news and feature photos, video optimized for mobile use and will capture credible, shareable visual cross-platform stories. This course is taught at Centennial College and is open only to students in the Specialist (Joint) program in Journalism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Visual Storytelling: Photography and Videography
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 10.0 credits, including JOUB01H3 and JOUB02H3 and ACMB02H3
cmCourseInfo.corequisitesText: JOUA06H3 and JOUB11H3 and JOUB14H3 and JOUB19H3

cmCourseInfo.description: To develop stories from raw numbers, students will navigate spreadsheets and databases, and acquire raw data from web pages. Students will learn to use Freedom of Information requests to acquire data. This course is taught at Centennial College and is open only to students in the Specialist (Joint) program in Journalism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Data Management and Presentation
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: [10.0 credits, including: JOUA01H3 and JOUA02H3 and JOUB01H3 and JOUB02H3 and ACMB02H3]andstudents must have a minimum CGPA of 2.0

cmCourseInfo.description: Building the blending of traditional skills in reporting and writing with interactive production protocols for digital news. The course provides an introduction to web development and coding concepts. This course is taught at Centennial College and is open only to students in the Specialist (Joint) program in Journalism.

courses.name: Journalism in the Age of Digital Media

cmCourseInfo.description: Journalism is undergoing a revolutionary change. Old trusted formats are falling away and young people are consuming, producing, exchanging, and absorbing news in a different way. The course will help students critically analyze new media models and give them the road map they will need to negotiate and work in New Media.
cmCourseInfo.title: Journalism in the Age of Digital Media

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Indicator: R

Restricted to students in the following groups:
SCSPEJOU - Specialist (Joint) Program in Journalism
SCMAJJSS - Major Program in Media, Journalism and Digital Cultures (Arts) - Journalism Studies Stream

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of the standard rules and techniques of journalistic writing. The course examines the basics of good writing style including words and structures most likely to cause problems for writers. Students will develop their writing skills through assignments designed to help them conceive, develop, and produce works of journalism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Fundamentals of Journalistic Writing
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: [(MDSA21H3) or JOUA01H3] and [(MDSA22H3) or JOUA02H3] and (HUMA01H3).

cmCourseInfo.description: This experiential learning course provides practical experience in communication, media and design industries, supporting the student-to-professional transition in advance of work placements, and graduation towards becoming practitioners in the field. This course is taught at Centennial College and is open only to students in the Specialist (Joint) program in Journalism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Storyworks
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: [12.0 credits, including: JOUA06H3, JOUB11H3, JOUB14H3, JOUB18H3 and JOUB19H3; students must have a minimum CGPA of 2.0

cmCourseInfo.description: From drones to virtual reality, and from augmented reality to artificial intelligence, this course will open students’ minds to innovation in storytelling and communications and provide opportunities to discover and explore through interaction with leading-edge practitioners in communications and journalism. This course is taught at Centennial College and is open only to students in the Specialist (Joint) program in Journalism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Emerging Tools and Technology

courses.name: Critical Approaches to Style, Form and Narrative

cmCourseInfo.description: The forms of Journalism are being challenged as reporting styles diverge and change overtime, across genres and media. New forms of narrative experimentation are opened up by the Internet and multimedia platforms. How do participatory cultures challenge journalists to experiment with media and language to create new audience experiences?
cmCourseInfo.title: Critical Approaches to Style, Form and Narrative
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: MDSB05H3 and JOUB39H3
cmCourseInfo.note: Priority will be given to students in the Specialist (Joint) program in Journalism.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Indicator: R

Year 4 - SCMAJJSS - Major Program in Media, Journalism and Digital Cultures (Arts) - Journalism Studies Stream

cmCourseInfo.description: New media technologies enable more production and distribution of culturally, ethnically and linguistically diverse voices than ever before. Who produces these diverse voices and how accessible are these media? This course explores various types of diasporic media from century-old newspapers to young and hip news and magazine blogs, produced by and for members of a multicultural society. Same as MDSC34H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Diasporic Media
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: [2.0 credits at the B-level in MDS courses] or [2.0 credits at the B-level in JOU courses] or [4.5 credits from the Major (Joint) program in New Media Studies Group I and Group II courses]

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduces students to ethical issues in media. Students learn theoretical aspects of ethics and apply them to media industries and practices in the context of advertising, public relations, journalism, mass media entertainment, and online culture. Same as MDSC63H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Media Ethics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ACMB01H3 and [[MDSA01H3 and MDSB05H3] or [JOUA01H3 and JOUA02H3]]

courses.name: Understanding Audiences in the Digital Age

cmCourseInfo.description: Understanding the interests and goals of audiences is a key part of media production. This course introduces communication research methods including ratings, metrics, in-depth interviews, and focus groups. The focus of class discussion and research project is to use these methods to be able to understand the nature of audiences’ media use in the digital age. Same as MDSC25H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Understanding Audiences in the Digital Age
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: [2.0 credits at the B level in MDS courses] or [2.0 credits at the B level in JOU courses] or [4.5 credits from the Major (Joint) program in New Media Studies Group I and Group II courses]

cmCourseInfo.description: A project-oriented capstone course requiring students to demonstrate the skills and knowledge necessary for contemporary journalism. Students will create a project that will serve as part of a portfolio or as a scholarly exploration of the state of the mass media. This course is open only to students in the Journalism Joint Program.
cmCourseInfo.title: Senior Seminar in Journalism
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: JOUB03H3 and JOUC13H3 and JOUC25H3

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Indicator: R

courses.name: Senior Research Seminar in Media and Journalism

cmCourseInfo.description: Focusing on independent research, this course requires students to demonstrate the necessary analysis, research and writing skills required for advanced study. This seminar course provides the essential research skills for graduate work and other research-intensive contexts. Students will design and undertake unique and independent research about the state of journalism. Same as MDSD11H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Senior Research Seminar in Media and Journalism
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ACMB02H3 and [an additional 4.5 credits in MDS or JOU courses, 1.0 credit of which must be at the C-level]
cmCourseInfo.note: Priority will be given to students in the Specialist (Joint) program in Journalism.
